comments.commentBody: Northern Italian cuisine really has more in common with that of France - lots of milk and butter - than does the fare in the South, the region of origin for most Italian immigrants. Look at a map: Bologna is in the North. Expect the cucina bolognesa to have lots of "dubiously Italian" items, it's not the same Italy as Naples or Sicily.
Marc, unlike French "cooking" there is no single Italian cooking.  That goes, as well, for the use of butter.

Butter, and plenty of it - is used in Northern Italian cooking, including in Bologna.  Historically olive oil was not as common, as inexpensive, or as easy to get a hold of in the northern areas as it is today.

Butter?! Nonsense. Like so many Hazan recipes, it makes this dubiously "italian".

No butter! No "vegetable oil", use olive oil. The recipe calls for too much tomato, consider cutting back. Add some pancetta before the bulk of the meat.

Instead of ground beef, try a medium cut of beef and hand-chop. If ground, use a coarse grind.

(Frankly, I can't understand the fascination with Hazan's recipes and even less why people feel they are italian. They are far from authentic italian recipes.)

He is open, friendly, just completed his education as a plastics technologist with excellent grades, and has a great job lined up as soon as he finishes his mandatory boot camp in the Swiss army. One of my good friends at work is a second generation Turk, born in Germany, who is completing his PhD in economics and has an excellent shot for a tenure track professorship at a good university. Both are Muslim, and you know what? It is not a problem - they are about as religious as I am. I go to church from time to time, but have the intelligence to make my own opinions, as do our friends.
Of course, there are fundamentalist Muslims who cause a lot of trouble, in Europe, America, and everywhere else. I was on the school board, and we had large problems with evangelical Christians, who did not want their children to participate in certain classes (evolution, sex education, both mandatory), did not want their children to go on overnight trips, and wanted to exempt them from certain Swiss traditions, such as an evening parade with jack'o'lanterns made from turnips, because it was a "heathen" tradition.

A grave concern for many Europeans is that areas where Muslim people have already lived for years are essentially enclaves, separate from the host country, many not speaking the language of their host nations with absolutely no interest in 'assimilating'.

Islam is a philosophy at odds with many tenets of European democracies, its code of conduct is rigidly spelled out, no dissent is allowed as the word of the prophet through the Koran is unchallenged.

In Western societies, though we may fiercely disagree with other people on many issues, tolerance of other views is a fundamental part of our way of life. Separation of church and state, though clearly going through rough waters in our nation, is the law of the land. Individuals are free to live the lives they wish within the law and choose the religion they wish to follow, or no religion. Moderating attitudes toward same sex unions and marriages is much more widely accepted today. Freedom of the press and individual rights are a key element of our culture and our lives.

It is hard to conceive how large numbers of Muslim people living within other nations and societies, which hold beliefs and views antithetical to their own, are going to coexist. It seems a breeding ground for mistrust, the potential for conflict and violence is strong. This experiment of allowing huge numbers of migrants into host countries, with no real idea or plan how this experiment will work out, is a recipe for future disaster.

What people like about Trump is that he answers the question asked and says what he thinks, not what he's been coached to say. JEB! and others were clearly doing the latter, and it showed. When the moderators' initial question was whether any of the debaters wouldn't pledge to support the winning candidate, anyone watching the debate immediately knew the moderators were out to get him, and when Megyn Kelly immediately followed by asking him about his disparaging remarks about women over the years, it was obvious she was doing the same. (The next day Rupert Murdoch praised his moderators--surprise, surprise!) When Trump was asked about giving money to Hillary, people also knew his answer (i.e., that campaign donations buy influence) was right, and when he said he'd given money to many of the debaters on the stage for the same reason and that the process is broken, he was saying what people know to be true. It's the elephant in the room no establishment candidate is supposed to mention. Unfortunately, this is true of both parties, and only Trump and Bernie Sanders are willing to admit it, which is a big reason both are unexpectedly popular in a way that neither the Republican or Democratic National Committees anticipated. It will be interesting to see how they try to bring these two down now that the genie is out of the bottle.

This is what happens when you take an authority originally established to operate bridges and tunnels and levy tolls to pay for improvements, and turn it into an unwieldy patronage-ridden "economic development" agency empowered to finance all kinds of unrelated projects and levy unrelated user fees.  It's even worse when it's a bi-state authority with such powers, given the inevitable horse-trading that goes on to use the authority's revenues to replace what otherwise would have been tax funded or privately financed.  The same thing is happening at the other end of New Jersey with the NJ/PA bi-state Delaware River Port Authority, only on a somewhat smaller scale.
Don't forget using state money to hire an expensive law firm to run a white wash investigation that didn't bother to interview many key players before declaring Christie innocentn

So Chris Christie says he should be held accountable for what happens on his watch, then qualified that by adding that he doesn't see what happens every day.  He also did not ask why an ostensibly pointless traffic study was being run, or respond to angry NJ commuters that their time was being squandered by said study.  Had the Governor been a concerned leader, 'Bridgegate' could have been halted.  When news of the traffic scheme broke, Christie could have been accountable by showing seriousness and pursuing to follow through.  Instead, he joked about being 'the guy moving the cones.'  When the full revelations broke, Christie again failed to make himself accountable.  He threw himself a pity party of a news conference, saying he had been lied to and presenting himself as the victim in all this, showing no remorse for all the citizens who actually had been hurt by the setup.  Accountability is an empty word for Governor Christie.

Recall that bridge and road tolls are justified for--and originally intended to--pay the costs of construction and maintenance.

But they've become a cesspool of hidden taxes on people who can't pay the high costs of living closer to their job.

And they are a way to bribe unions (of toll takers), pay unrelated expenses of governments, add to a slush fund.
